Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Thermal Ionization Mass Spectrometer (TIMS) for high-precision isotopic research of the Earth's mantle, crust and oceans
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will provide funds to acquire a modern Thermal Ionization Mass Spectrometer (TIMS) instrument. The TIMS instrument will form an integral component of research into fundamental Earth processes and will be an invaluable tool for teaching a variety of core principles to undergraduate and graduate students, including techniques for sample preparation, mass spectrometry, and data interpretation and analysis. Existing instrumental facilities have a strong history of supporting external users and providing teaching and training in sample preparation, metrology and engaging the scientific community through short-courses. The new TIMS instrument will serve students and faculty in Earth science, geography and archaeology, and will provide training and data to collaborating researchers, students and postdoctoral fellows from at least eight different colleges and universities in the region, many of which are undergraduate and/or Hispanic-serving institutions.

The new TIMS instrument will transform institutional research capabilities for making high-precision isotopic measurements to carry-out NSF-funded research addressing themes including the timescales of metamorphism and melting of continental crust, the ages and origins of mantle reservoirs, time-scales of early-Earth differentiation, magmatic processes at mid-ocean ridge systems, and reconstruction of changes in ocean circulation and climate variability ranging from millennial to geologic time scales. The arrival of the new TIMS instrument will coincide with completion of a new, dedicated clean laboratory facility and a separate, climate-controlled instrument room. All five principle investigators on this award currently have NSF-funded research (Earth Sciences, Ocean Sciences, Polar Programs) that will make immediate and extensive use of the new TIMS instrument.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary objective of the proposal is to acquire a modern Thermal Ionization Mass Spectrometer (TIMS) in the Department of Earth Science at the University of California, Santa Barbara. With funds from this proposal, we purchased a Thermo Triton Plus outfitted with five 10-teraohm amplifiers. The new instrument replaces the 35-year-old TIMS at UCSB, which was the centerpiece of the long-term, successful geochemistry–geochronology research program. A modern TIMS has transformed our ability to make the most precise isotopic measurements, enabling us to push new frontiers in Earth Science. The cohort of five PIs have a broad range of research—including timescales of metamorphism and melting of continental crust, the ages and origins of mantle reservoirs, time-scales of early-Earth differentiation, magmatic processes at mid-ocean ridge systems, and reconstruction of changes in ocean circulation and climate variability ranging from millennial to geologic time scales—and the new UCSB TIMS allows the PIs to carry out NSF-funded TIMS-based research in several across several NSF programs (EAR, OCE, Polar Programs).

We are well along the way toward having a dynamic analytical facility that fosters exciting new research and training opportunities afforded by a state-of-the-art instrument. Since the instrument was determined to be fully functional in April 2019 (following installation in late 2018), five graduate students, a post-doc, and two undergraduates have all gained experience as trained and independent TIMS users. We have focused the last 10 months of development efforts toward micro-analysis of Sr isotopes in samples hosting as little as 200 picograms of Sr (with total procedural blanks down to 3 picograms) and Nd isotopes in samples hosting as little as 100 picograms of Nd (with total procedural blanks down to 220 femtograms). These analytical capabilities allow us to target single olivine-hosted melt inclusions, and single mineral grain (olivine, orthopyroxene, and clinopyroxene) analyses in magmas and peridotites. Looking forward, we will continue to expand our analytical toolset to include Os, Pb, Cr and Ca, with the primary goal of teaching and training the next generation of isotope geochemists in the Earth Sciences.
